Law of Composition

A law of composition on a set $M$ is a map from $M \times M$ to $M$. It is characterized by the assignment $(a, b) \longmapsto a \cdot b$ for $(a, b) \in M \times M$, and in many cases, the image of a given pair $(a, b)$ is written as a "product" $a \cdot b$ or $ab$.
Order of a group
The order of a group $G$, denoted as ord $G$, is defined as the number of elements in $G$ if $G$ is finite. If $G$ is infinite, its order is said to be infinite.
Subring

A subset S of a ring R is called a subring if S is a subgroup with respect to the addition on R and a submonoid with respect to the multiplication on R. S inherits the laws of composition from R and is itself a ring.
Ideal

Let $R$ be a ring. A subset $\mathfrak{a} \subset R$ is called an ideal in $R$ if: (i) $\mathfrak{a}$ is an additive subgroup of $R$. (ii) For any $r \in R$ and $a \in \mathfrak{a}$, it holds that $ra \in \mathfrak{a}$.
Least common multiple

An element $v \in R$ is called a least common multiple of $x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n} \in R$ if: (i) $x_{i} \mid v$ for $i=1, \ldots, n$, i.e., $v$ is a common multiple of all the $x_{i}$. (ii) If $a \in R$ is a common multiple of the $x_{i}$, i.e., if $x_{i} \mid a$ for $i=1, \ldots, n$, then $v \mid a$.
Localization of a Ring

Given a ring $R$ and a multiplicative system $S \subset R$, the localization $S^{-1}R$ (or $R_S$) is the ring of fractions $ rac{a}{s}$ where $a \in R$ and $s \in S$, under an equivalence relation defined by $ rac{a}{s} =  rac{a'}{s'}$ if there exists some $s'' \in S$ such that $as's'' = a'ss''$.
Subfield
A subring $T$ of a field $K$ is called a subfield if $T$ is a field itself.
Finite Ring Homomorphism

A ring homomorphism $\varphi: A \longrightarrow B$ is finite if $B$ is a finite $A$-module under $\varphi$. This is also referred to as $B$ being finite over $A$ or, if $\varphi$ is an inclusion homomorphism, that the extension $A \hookrightarrow B$ is finite.
Normal field extension

A normal field extension is an extension field that is the splitting field of a family of polynomials from the base field. It is a prestage to Galois extensions. An algebraic field extension \\(K \subset L\\) is called normal if it satisfies the equivalent conditions of Theorem 4: (i) Every \\(K\\)-homomorphism \\(L \longrightarrow \bar{L}\\) into an algebraic closure \\(\bar{L}\\) of \\(L\\) restricts to an automorphism of \\(L\\). (ii) \\(L\\) is a splitting field of a family of polynomials in \\(K[X]\\). (iii) Every irreducible polynomial in \\(K[X]\\) that admits a zero in \\(L\\) decomposes over \\(L\\) completely into linear factors.
Galois group of a Field Extension
The Galois group $\\operatorname{Gal}(L / K)$ of an extension $L / K$ is the group of all field automorphisms of $L$ that fix every element of $K$.
r-cycle
A cycle involving $r$ elements is called an $r$-cycle and is denoted as $\pi = (x_{1}, \ldots, x_{r})$.
Domain
The domain of a function is the set of all possible input values for which the function is defined. Every input value in the domain has a corresponding output in the codomain via the function.
Definition_Association_Analysis

Implied_Association_Relationships.Explanation: A subring is defined as a subset of a ring that inherits the laws of composition from the ring. Therefore, the concept of a law of composition must be defined to understand what a subring is.

An ideal is defined as a subset of a ring that is an additive subgroup and satisfies certain properties with respect to the ring's multiplication. Thus, the concept of a ring, which includes laws of composition, must be defined first.
The least common multiple is defined in terms of divisibility within a ring. Therefore, the concept of a ring, which includes laws of composition, must be defined first.
Localization of a ring involves creating a new ring from an existing ring and a multiplicative system. Thus, the concept of a ring, which includes laws of composition, must be defined first.
A subfield is defined as a subring of a field that is itself a field. Therefore, the concept of a subring must be defined first.
A finite ring homomorphism is a ring homomorphism where the codomain is a finite module over the domain. Thus, the concept of a ring, which includes laws of composition, must be defined first.
A normal field extension is defined as an extension field that is the splitting field of a family of polynomials from the base field. Therefore, the concept of a field must be defined first.

The Galois group of a field extension is defined as the group of all field automorphisms of an extension field that fix every element of the base field. Therefore, the concept of a field extension must be defined first.
